Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: The grandfather learns that a family member is dealing with a significant personal crisis.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Story: I was in the middle of delivering jury instructions when my clerk slipped me a note—urgent, in red ink. The Supreme Court had just overturned the very precedent I was relying on. My mind raced; I knew I had to halt everything, review the new ruling, and adjust my instructions. The courtroom was silent, all eyes on me, waiting for my next words. At that moment, my phone buzzed in my pocket—a rare breach of protocol, but I’d left it on for a reason. My daughter’s message flashed on the screen: “Dad, it’s about Ben. Please call as soon as you can.” Ben, my grandson, had been struggling lately, and I’d promised to be there for him, to keep in touch, to help him through this crisis. The weight of my robe felt heavier than ever. I was expected to be the pillar of justice, unwavering and precise, but also the steady, loving presence my family needed. I stood there, torn, the demands of the bench and my family pulling me in opposite directions, unsure which duty to answer first.
